passages.text: France's economy has recently underperformed the rest of Europe. Growth has slowed to below potential, government debt- to- GDP is on the rise, and 10- year borrowing rates are closer to Italy's than at any time in past decades. Recent events have reinforced political uncertainty and prompted questions regarding France's medium- term prospects. We outline here the structural challenges faced by France, as well as the opportunities.

We think France's main economic challenge will be to stabilise public debt. To that end, the government will eventually need to run a \(1\%\) of GDP primary surplus, compared with today's \(3\%\) primary deficit. The effort should, in our view, be focused on reducing public spending as a share of GDP given limited room for further tax increases. In addition, fiscal policy in France could adopt a more tailored response to future economic shocks and would benefit from a more robust independent evaluation framework.

Reducing public spending is therefore likely to remain a key issue. Government spending in France is currently among the highest in Europe, in particular on pensions, health, housing, and unemployment. Spending on defence and energy capacity have become highly strategic and are likely to increase further. Education and health spending can yield high social returns but have suffered from low efficiency. Other items, such as housing subsidies and intermunicipal government employment, show limited efficiency and are of lower strategic importance.

France will crucially need to resume structural reforms to boost growth. The employment rate of the young and old remains too low and the unemployment rate too high. Facilitating economic migration could boost skilled employment and help alleviate labour shortages. France also urgently needs to address the notable fall in mathematical skills, refocus policies designed to foster innovation, and further lower the regulatory burden on small firms.

Policymakers face key distributional issues. France remains a country with elevated pre- tax income inequalities and low social mobility. Tax revenues are skewed towards labour taxation, with taxes on wage income and social contributions accounting for \(60\%\) of all tax receipts. France's pay- as- you- go pension system is likely to return into deficit without further reforms, and low rates of return have sparked renewed interest in funded pension models.

France would stand to benefit from reforms at the European level. The integration of capital markets would allow savers to seek higher returns and firms to access easier funding. France remains a net contributor to the EU budget but might tap a future European loan programme given advantageous borrowing costs. And other policy priorities, such as defence spending and environmental policies, would be best tackled at the European level given economies of scale.

Despite these challenges, opportunities exist in the form of rethinking public spending more strategically, resuming reforms to boost growth, tackling key distributional issues, and leveraging Europe's scale. Meaningful progress is unlikely in the near term, given the ongoing political deadlock. But the outlook could become more balanced if political uncertainty abates, for instance after the next presidential elections in 2027.

France's economy has recently underperformed the rest of Europe. Growth has slowed to below potential, government debt- to- GDP is on the rise, and 10- year borrowing rates are closer to Italy's than at any time in past decades. Recent events have reinforced political uncertainty, leading investors to ask about France's medium- term prospects. We outline here the structural challenges faced by France as well as the opportunities.

We think France's main economic challenge will be to stabilise public debt. The debt- to- GDP ratio in France has increased steadily since the 1970s, reaching \(114\%\) earlier this year, and we forecast a further rise to \(120\%\) by 2030 (Exhibit 1, left). Public debt in France is now the third- highest in the Euro area, behind Italy and Greece.
Exhibit 1: The Priority of Economic Policy Should Be to Stabilise Public Debt by Reducing the Deficit
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
The reason behind the current increase in debt is France's large public deficit. At \(5.8\%\) of GDP in 2024, the government deficit is large by historical standards and in

comparison to a relatively health economy. And, unlike Italy or Greece, where large interest payments hide primary surpluses, France is running one of the largest primary deficits among developed economies (Exhibit 1, right).

How far should the government reduce the deficit? Under our central assumptions of \(1\%\) real growth, \(2\%\) inflation, and \(3.5\%\) borrowing rates, stabilising the debt ratio at \(120\%\) would require running a \(0.5\%\) primary surplus (Exhibit 2, left). And we estimate that a target of \(3\%\) robust to macroeconomic shocks would aim for a larger surplus of between \(1\%\) and \(2\%\) , a rare occurrence for France in post- war history.

The pace of deficit reduction has so far been moderate due to the political deadlock in parliament, with the primary balance set to improve 0.6pp in 2025. Going forward, the optimal pace of deficit reduction should carefully balance the positive impact on debt of moving too slow and the negative impact on growth of going too fast. Experts at France's Council of Economic Analysis have therefore advocated for a steady 0.5pp/year improvement in the primary balance with a somewhat larger effort at the start.
Exhibit 2: We Think The Government Should Aim for a \(1\%\) Primary Surplus and Focus on Reducing Spending as a Share of GDP
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Eurostat, Insee, OECD

We see two reasons why it would be preferable for the policy mix to skew towards a reduction in public spending (as a share of GDP) rather than an increase in public revenues. First, France already has one of the largest government revenues among developed economies, suggesting little room for further increases (Exhibit 2, right). Second, academic studies and our own research have shown that spending- led efforts tend to be more successful in sustainably reducing the deficit.

In addition, fiscal policy in France could adopt a more tailored response to future economic shocks. To be sure, the large response at the onset of the Covid pandemic was justified (in particular because of the ex ante uncertainty) and was ultimately comparable to peers. But the ceiling on gas and electricity prices during the energy

crisis (the so- called "bouclier tarifaire") did not incentivise lower consumption and was not targeted at lower- income households. As a result, real- time estimates show that France had earmarked more fiscal support than other countries relative to its reliance on gas (Exhibit 3, left).
Exhibit 3: Fiscal Policy Could Adopt a More Tailored Response to Future Economic Shocks and Would Benefit From a More Robust Independent Evaluation Framework

On the left, allocated fiscal support is the average of OECD, IMF and Brugeel estimates. Figures are generally higher than the observed outturn because energy prices ended up realising lower than energy futures used in real-time forecasts.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, OECD, IMF, Brugeel

Lastly, fiscal policy in France could benefit from a more robust institutional framework. The government's growth projections receive little external oversight and have been too optimistic in recent years. Moreover, France has no independent costing process to assess the impact of policy proposals on the economic and fiscal outlook. One of the reasons for this is that France's independent fiscal institution, the High Council of Public Finance, has a narrower mandate and has much lower staffing levels than that of other developed countries (Exhibit 3, right).

Reducing public spending is therefore likely to remain a key issue. In that respect, it is helpful to compare where France spends more than other European countries. Recent analysis by Banque de France showed that the difference as of 2023 was broad- based, albeit mostly attributable to spending on social protection, which includes spending on pensions, health, housing, and unemployment (Exhibit 4).
Exhibit 4: Most of the Difference Between Public Spending in France and the Rest of Europe Comes From Social Protection
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Banque de France

Defence spending has become highly strategic and is due to increase further, given greater geopolitical risks and more ambitious NATO commitments (Exhibit 5, left). Public spending on defence could be particularly impactful if it helps the military industry to build capacity and cements France's role as an arms exporter in the region and worldwide.
Exhibit 5: France Has Long Spent on Maintaining Military and Nuclear Production Capacity
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,SIPRI,Eurostat

Events in recent years have also underlined the strategic importance of energy policy. In that respect, the nationalisation of electricity producer EDF in 2023 showed the commitment of France to maintain nuclear production capacity (Exhibit 5, right). Some of France's other environmental policies (such as household renovation subsidies) are also generally judged to be well- calibrated. Broadening out domestic carbon pricing would be a cost- effective way to make progress on meeting emission mitigation targets, even though the 2018 "yellow vest" protests underlined the importance of taking into account distributional implications.

Education spending can generate high social returns in the long run by boosting human capital and fostering innovation. For instance, academic studies suggest that France's recent decrease in primary school class sizes will eventually be self- financed (Exhibit 6, left). At the same time, the large resources devoted to education in France have led to lower results compared with other countries. Experts at the Council of Economic Analysis have therefore called for the government to focus on increasing the efficiency of education spending, for instance, by reducing the number of students repeating an academic year and strengthening teacher evaluation.
Exhibit 6: Education and Health Spending Have Strategic Aspects but Often Demonstrate Low Efficiency

On the right, we construct a "composite health index" similar to Teodoro and Ruud (2023) as the average percentile rank of a country's life expectancy, infant mortality, and subjective health status as measured by the OECD.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, OECD

The concept of spending efficiency is particularly relevant for health policy. France is one of the countries with the highest public spending on health and yet does not rank particularly highly on measures such as life expectancy and infant mortality (Exhibit 6, right). In other words, France is far away from the "efficiency frontier" of countries achieving the best health outcome for a given public amount spent. In response, the government has recently proposed measures to rein in public spending on prescription medicine and medical leave.

In some cases, public spending does not appear to demonstrate a high social return or make a particularly strategic contribution. There is little evidence, for instance, that higher housing subsidies in France have lowered the housing share of household expenditure (Exhibit 7, left). And the increase in intermunicipal government employment has not been accompanied by a corresponding decrease in the number of other local government employment or a broadening of intermunicipal government competencies (Exhibit 7, right).
Exhibit 7: Spending on Housing Subsidy and Intermunicipal Government Employment Have Demonstrated Limited Effectiveness
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,OECD,DGAFP

In our view, it is also crucial that France resumes structural reforms to boost growth. Starting with the labour market, the employment rate of the young and the old is still too low in France compared with Northern European countries (Exhibit 8, left). Future reforms should therefore seek to facilitate entry of the young into the labour market and allow for a more gradual exit of the old.

Moreover, the unemployment rate remains high at \(7.5\%\) . While the government has continued to tighten unemployment benefits, a striking feature remains the lack of degressivity (the pace at which benefits decline while someone is out of work) throughout the first two years of unemployment in France compared with Northern European countries (Exhibit 8, right).2
Exhibit 8: France Needs Labour Market Reforms to Boost the Employment Rate of the Young and the Old and Reduce Unemployment
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Eurostat, OECD

Facilitating economic migration would be another way to lean against demographic headwinds. In particular, experts at the Council of Economic Analysis showed that the foreign population in France is less educated than in other developed countries, pointing to potential upside in attracting more international talent (Exhibit 9, left). Moreover, job vacancy rates are the highest in sectors already employing the most foreign workers, suggesting scope for migration to ease labour market shortages (Exhibit 9, right).
Exhibit 9: Facilitating Economic Migration Could Boost Skilled Employment and Help Alleviate Labour Shortages
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Eurostat, OECD, Insee

The elevated number of job vacancies without a corresponding decline in unemployment suggests that France's labour market struggles to re- allocate workers from one sector to another. One likely explanation is that labour market dynamics remain sluggish in France. Berkeley economist Benjamin Schoefer, for instance, showed that the share of "young jobs" formed within the past year was smaller in France than other developed countries (Exhibit 10, left). Some potential reasons include the design of unemployment insurance and seniority- driven employment protection.
Exhibit 10: The Labour Market Remains Rigid and Mathematical Skills Have Fallen Notably
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Schoefer (2025),OECD

The notable fall in mathematical skills also needs to be addressed (Exhibit 10, right). Experts at the Council of Economic Analysis estimate that a similar reaction to the German "PlSA shock" in the early 2000s (when poor test scores spurred significant educational reforms) could lift growth by 0.2pp. Moreover, academic studies have found considerable upside in broadening the social- economic background of scientists and innovators - a phenomenon that LSE economist Xavier Jaravel has coined the "lost Marie Curies" for France.

Policies designed to foster innovation could be better focused. For instance, academic research showed that R&D tax credits in France have a more positive impact on small- and medium- sized firms, yet large firms claim the largest share of available funds (Exhibit 11, left). Other studies showed that closer proximity to public research groups in France led to significant R&D spillovers for private firms, suggesting there is significant upside to tap in France's leading universities.
Exhibit 11: France Could Revamp Innovation Incentives and Decrease the Regulatory Burden on Small Firms
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Aghion et al. (2022), France Strategie, EIB

Finally, the regulatory burden on small firms remains too high. Survey evidence shows that small firms allocate a greater share of staff than large firms to meeting regulatory requirements, likely diverting resources away from innovation (Exhibit 11, right). Moreover, regulatory hurdles in France often increase with a company's size, which deters small firms from bringing their innovation up to scale.

Policymakers face key distributional issues. In the first place, France has limited income inequalities (as measured by the Gini coefficient) but only after taxes and transfers. In fact, France is one of the most unequal developed countries in terms of income before the government intervenes (Exhibit 12, left). Recent studies also showed that social mobility (as measured by intergenerational income correlation) is among the lowest in France (Exhibit 12, right). The upshot is that public policies in France still fall short of providing equality of opportunity.
Exhibit 12: Inequality Before Taxes and Transfers Remain High and Social Mobility Remains Low
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, OECD, Kenedi and Siruge (2023)

In addition, the composition of tax revenues will likely remain at the centre of the policy debate. Tax revenues in France are skewed towards labour taxation, with taxes on wage income and social contributions amounting to \(60\%\) of total tax revenues (Exhibit 13). In contrast, corporate income and consumption taxation (such as VAT) represent a smaller share of tax revenues than in other developed countries. Recent policy proposals have included funding a cut in social contributions with a VAT increase, increasing the progressivity of inheritance taxation, and levying a wealth tax on ultra- high net worths.
Exhibit 13: The Composition of Tax Revenue Skews Towards Labour Taxation
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,OECD

The future of France's pay- as- you- go pension system will likely be debated, too. The 2023 pension reform raised the statutory retirement age from 62 to 64 years and limited the pension system deficit until 2030. But the Pension Advisory Council predicts that the system's deficit would then continue to increase, unless the retirement age is raised further, pension contributions are increased, or pension benefits are decreased (Exhibit 14, left). Importantly, the system's low rate of return (because of an increasing dependency ratio and subdued productivity growth) has come into focus and sparked renewed interest in funded pension models (Exhibit 14, right).
Exhibit 14: The Pension System Deficit Is Projected to Increase While Returns Remain Low
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,UN,Eurostat,Pension Advisory Council

France would also stand to benefit from reforms at the European level. The integration of capital markets would allow savers to seek higher returns and firms to access easier funding. That is because lowering the home bias in regulatory and tax frameworks could incentivise savers in France to increase their exposure to regional equity markets
(Exhibit 15, left). And the pooling of funds could provide the volumes needed by start- ups to scale up in Europe instead of the US (Exhibit 15, right).
Exhibit 15: France Would Benefit From Capital Markets Reform at the European Level
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Eurostat, Strebulaev (2024)

Fiscal integration in Europe made a leap forward during the Covid pandemic with the launch of joint borrowing under the NGEU facility. France is a net contributor to the EU budget and would likely remain so when NGEU repayment starts in 2028 (Exhibit 16, left). But EU debt now trades at a lower spread to Germany than France, which could incentivise France to tap a future European loan programme (Exhibit 16, right).
Exhibit 16: France Remains a Net Contributor to the European Budget but Could Now Benefit From Lower Borrowing Cost
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Eurostat, Goldman Sachs FICC and Equities

France could also leverage Europe's scale on other policy issues, in particular as part of the 2028- 2034 EU budget. Joint procurement in defence could help France secure lower costs for its purchases and greater demand for its products. And environmental policies (including carbon pricing) are also best expressed at the EU level.

France undoubtedly faces a number of economic challenges, in particular that of stabilising the country's public debt. But opportunities exist in the form of rethinking public spending more strategically, resuming reforms to boost growth, tackling key distributional issues, and leveraging Europe's scale. Meaningful progress is unlikely in the near term, given the ongoing political deadlock. But the outlook could become more balanced if political uncertainty abates, for instance after the next presidential elections in 2027.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial product(s), data or offering(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
